file_metadata.authors: ["2 computational network analysis", "CRISPR-enabled in vivo disease modeling", "9 2 Laboratory of Mucosal Barrier Pathobiology", "Department of Pathology", "Brigham and Women’s", "17 * Contributed equally to this manuscript", "21 CLSB5", "3 Blackfan Circle"]
file_metadata.title: Injunction. One Operating a Bus Line without Required License May Be Enjoined by One Who Has License

chunks.text: Many neurodevelopmental genetic disorders, such as Rett syndrome, are caused by a single gene mutation but trigger changes in expression and regulation of numerous other genes, impacting multiple organ systems beyond the CNS, making it challenging to develop broadly effective treatments. This challenge is compounded by the lack of sufficiently broad and biologically relevant drug screens and the complexity of identifying clinically relevant targets responsible for diverse phenotypes. This study combined human gene regulatory network-based computational drug prediction with in vivo screening in a population-level diversity, CRISPR-edited, Xenopus laevis tadpole model of Rett syndrome for target-agnostic drug discovery, leading to the identification of vorinostat. Vorinostat improved both CNS and non-CNS abnormalities in a pre-clinical mouse model, demonstrating pre-clinical efficacy across multiple organ systems when dosed after symptom onset. Network analysis revealed a putative therapeutic mechanism involving acetylation metabolism and microtubule post-translational modifications. While considered an HDAC inhibitor, vorinostat restored protein acetylation in both hypo- and hyperacetylated tissues, suggesting non-HDAC-mediated mechanisms supported by proteomic analysis.
chunks.chunk_summary: A combined computational and in vivo screening approach identified vorinostat as a potential Rett syndrome treatment with broad efficacy across multiple organ systems, suggesting a novel mechanism involving acetylation metabolism and microtubule modifications.
chunks.authors: ["2 computational network analysis", "CRISPR-enabled in vivo disease modeling", "9 2 Laboratory of Mucosal Barrier Pathobiology", "Department of Pathology", "Brigham and Women’s", "17 * Contributed equally to this manuscript", "21 CLSB5", "3 Blackfan Circle"]

chunks.text: Rett Syndrome (Rett) is a neurodevelopmental disorder affecting multiple organs, primarily caused by mutations in the MeCP2 gene, a transcriptional repressor and activator. Cellular heterogeneity, with mixed wild-type and mutant cells, leads to widespread gene misregulation. While research focuses on CNS symptoms like neuromotor and cognitive impairments, patients also experience respiratory dysfunction, gastrointestinal issues, inflammation, and metabolic disruptions, contributing significantly to morbidity.  Although gene therapy is theoretically possible, challenges remain regarding delivery and dosage compensation.  Current pharmaceutical treatments like trofinetide and sarizotan have shown limited efficacy, primarily targeting CNS symptoms. This study presents an integrated approach combining gene expression network computational modeling and in vivo screening in a Xenopus tadpole model to identify drugs restoring multi-organ system function in Rett syndrome.
chunks.chunk_summary: Rett syndrome, caused by MeCP2 mutations, presents a complex therapeutic challenge due to its multi-organ effects and limitations of current treatments, prompting the need for new approaches like the integrated computational and in vivo screening presented in this study.
chunks.authors: ["2 computational network analysis", "CRISPR-enabled in vivo disease modeling", "9 2 Laboratory of Mucosal Barrier Pathobiology", "Department of Pathology", "Brigham and Women’s", "17 * Contributed equally to this manuscript", "21 CLSB5", "3 Blackfan Circle"]

chunks.text: Xenopus embryos and tadpoles were housed and fed under controlled conditions, with all procedures approved by the HMS Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee. MeCP2 homologs in Xenopus laevis were identified using Xenbase, with Cas9 target sites selected using CHOPCHOP to minimize off-target effects. Guide RNAs targeting exons coding for the methyl-CpG-binding domain and Transcriptional repression domain were synthesized. CRISPR RNP complexes were prepared and injected into 4-cell stage embryos, resulting in mosaic MeCP2 knockdown.  The injected RNP amount was optimized to achieve efficient gene editing without toxicity. Embryos were then raised to tadpole stages for experiments.
chunks.chunk_summary: A CRISPR-Cas9 system was used to generate mosaic MeCP2 knockdown in Xenopus laevis tadpoles, with careful optimization of injection parameters to balance editing efficiency and minimize toxicity.
chunks.authors: ["2 computational network analysis", "CRISPR-enabled in vivo disease modeling", "9 2 Laboratory of Mucosal Barrier Pathobiology", "Department of Pathology", "Brigham and Women’s", "17 * Contributed equally to this manuscript", "21 CLSB5", "3 Blackfan Circle"]

chunks.text: MeCP2 editing efficiency was assessed using Indel Detection by Amplicon Analysis (IDAA), which allows for precise measurement of indels. Primers were designed, amplicons purified, and fragment analysis performed. The IDAA method provided single-base resolution for analyzing the tetraploid Xenopus genome. Analysis of tadpoles with seizures showed varying editing efficiencies across different target sites, with an average out-of-frame indel ratio of approximately 47-82%. The majority of indels were small deletions, ranging from 1 to 30 bp.
chunks.chunk_summary: IDAA analysis confirmed successful MeCP2 gene disruption in Xenopus tadpoles, with varying editing efficiencies across target sites and a predominance of small deletions.
chunks.authors: ["2 computational network analysis", "CRISPR-enabled in vivo disease modeling", "9 2 Laboratory of Mucosal Barrier Pathobiology", "Department of Pathology", "Brigham and Women’s", "17 * Contributed equally to this manuscript", "21 CLSB5", "3 Blackfan Circle"]

chunks.text: Tadpoles were lysed, and RNA was extracted using a QIAGEN RNeasy mini kit. RNA samples underwent DNAse treatment. Microarray analysis was performed using Affymetrix Xenopus laevis Genome 2.0 Arrays. cDNA was synthesized, purified, fragmented, labeled, and hybridized to the arrays. Arrays were washed, stained, and scanned to obtain gene expression data.
chunks.chunk_summary: Gene expression profiling was performed on Xenopus tadpoles using Affymetrix microarrays, following standard RNA extraction, cDNA synthesis, and hybridization procedures.
chunks.authors: ["2 computational network analysis", "CRISPR-enabled in vivo disease modeling", "9 2 Laboratory of Mucosal Barrier Pathobiology", "Department of Pathology", "Brigham and Women’s", "17 * Contributed equally to this manuscript", "21 CLSB5", "3 Blackfan Circle"]

chunks.text: Microarray and RNAseq datasets were normalized using RMA and size factors, respectively. Missing values were removed, and duplicates were combined. Gene expression heatmaps and hierarchical clustering were generated using limma and seaborn. Volcano plots were created using bioinfokit.
chunks.chunk_summary: Standard bioinformatics tools were used for normalization, visualization, and analysis of gene expression data from microarray and RNAseq experiments.
chunks.authors: ["2 computational network analysis", "CRISPR-enabled in vivo disease modeling", "9 2 Laboratory of Mucosal Barrier Pathobiology", "Department of Pathology", "Brigham and Women’s", "17 * Contributed equally to this manuscript", "21 CLSB5", "3 Blackfan Circle"]

chunks.text: The nemoCAD tool predicts drugs that shift MeCP2-edited tadpoles to a control state based on transcriptome data. It uses pre-computed drug-gene and gene-gene interaction probabilities and differential gene expression signatures. The algorithm identifies genes needing reversal to normalize the disease state. Pairwise analysis compares gene expression profiles of compounds from the LINCS database with the target normalization signature, calculating correlation statistics and a combination score. Putative predictions incorporating gene dependencies are generated using Bayesian network analysis on a regulatory and drug-gene interaction network. This network, built from public databases (KEGG, TRRUST, LINCS, CTD), encodes paths connecting genes and drugs, enabling a message-passing algorithm to rank drugs based on their probability of inducing the desired transcriptomic signature. Drugs are prioritized based on correlation with the desired transcriptional change and high probabilities of reversing the disease state. nemoCAD also visualizes network architecture, providing insights into potential molecular targets and enabling treatment optimization.
chunks.chunk_summary: nemoCAD predicts drugs reversing disease states by comparing transcriptomic signatures and using a Bayesian network approach to incorporate gene dependencies and rank drugs based on their probability of inducing the desired changes.
chunks.authors: ["2 computational network analysis", "CRISPR-enabled in vivo disease modeling", "9 2 Laboratory of Mucosal Barrier Pathobiology", "Department of Pathology", "Brigham and Women’s", "17 * Contributed equally to this manuscript", "21 CLSB5", "3 Blackfan Circle"]

chunks.text: Gene regulatory networks were inferred from gene expression data using GENIE3. Candidate regulator genes (BDNF, FCRL2, FMR1, MeCP2, NTRK2, PER1, PER2, PUM1) were selected based on Rett Syndrome mechanisms.  Networks were constructed for MeCP2 knockdown and control samples, visualizing the strongest relationships. Cross-species transcriptomics analysis compared gene networks in human patients, mouse, zebrafish, and Xenopus models using existing datasets. Data was normalized and transformed, and common genes were analyzed using PCA and UMAP. Heatmaps of differential gene expression were plotted, and gene networks were constructed using GENIE3. Edge weight distributions were assessed, and the strongest connections were visualized.  In-degree and out-degree were calculated to identify key regulator and target genes in the cross-species network.
chunks.chunk_summary: Gene regulatory networks were constructed and analyzed using GENIE3, comparing MeCP2 knockdown and control samples across different species to identify conserved sub-networks and key regulators and targets.
chunks.authors: ["2 computational network analysis", "CRISPR-enabled in vivo disease modeling", "9 2 Laboratory of Mucosal Barrier Pathobiology", "Department of Pathology", "Brigham and Women’s", "17 * Contributed equally to this manuscript", "21 CLSB5", "3 Blackfan Circle"]

chunks.text: Drugs were purchased and dissolved in DMSO. Compounds were diluted for screening, with media exchanged every two days. Dosing began at stage 45 and lasted for 7 days, followed by washout. Tadpole behavior was scored manually based on seizure-related phenotypes. Vorinostat and trofinetide for mouse studies were purchased and prepared for injection or oral dosing. Mice were dosed intraperitoneally or orally.
chunks.chunk_summary: Drug screening in tadpoles involved dosing via culture medium for 7 days, followed by washout, with behavior scored based on seizure phenotypes; mouse studies used intraperitoneal or oral administration of vorinostat and trofinetide.
chunks.authors: ["2 computational network analysis", "CRISPR-enabled in vivo disease modeling", "9 2 Laboratory of Mucosal Barrier Pathobiology", "Department of Pathology", "Brigham and Women’s", "17 * Contributed equally to this manuscript", "21 CLSB5", "3 Blackfan Circle"]

chunks.text: Tadpoles were euthanized, washed, and fixed. For sections, tadpoles were cryoprotected, embedded, sectioned, and mounted on slides. For whole-mount preparation, a published method was followed. In situ hybridization was performed on cryosections following manufacturer's instructions. Immunohistochemistry was performed on sections and whole mounts using various antibodies. Slides were washed, incubated with secondary antibodies, mounted, and imaged. Whole-mount immunofluorescence was performed using a published method, with primary and secondary antibody incubation followed by washing and mounting.
chunks.chunk_summary: Standard histological and immunostaining procedures were used to prepare and analyze Xenopus tadpole tissues, including cryosectioning, whole-mount preparation, in situ hybridization, and immunohistochemistry.
chunks.authors: ["2 computational network analysis", "CRISPR-enabled in vivo disease modeling", "9 2 Laboratory of Mucosal Barrier Pathobiology", "Department of Pathology", "Brigham and Women’s", "17 * Contributed equally to this manuscript", "21 CLSB5", "3 Blackfan Circle"]

chunks.text: Thermal proteome profiling was adapted for Xenopus tadpoles. Tadpoles were exposed to vorinostat or ivermectin, euthanized, and body segments were thermally treated. Samples were lysed, and insoluble material was removed. Supernatants were pooled, centrifuged, reduced, alkylated, and proteins were precipitated. Protein pellets were washed, resuspended, and digested with trypsin/LysC. Peptides were purified and analyzed by LC-MS/MS. Mass spectrometry acquisition was performed using a TripleTOF 6600 with electrospray interface and coupled to a Micro LC200. Data-independent acquisition was used with gas phase fractionation. Peptides were analyzed using a 3D ion library, and protein quantification was based on integrated peptides.
chunks.chunk_summary: Thermal proteome profiling was adapted for Xenopus tadpoles to identify drug targets, involving thermal treatment, lysis, protein precipitation, digestion, and LC-MS/MS analysis.
chunks.authors: ["2 computational network analysis", "CRISPR-enabled in vivo disease modeling", "9 2 Laboratory of Mucosal Barrier Pathobiology", "Department of Pathology", "Brigham and Women’s", "17 * Contributed equally to this manuscript", "21 CLSB5", "3 Blackfan Circle"]

chunks.text: MeCP2-null (MeCP2-/Y) and wild-type male mice were used, housed under specific-pathogen-free conditions. Mice were assessed for disease severity using phenotypic scoring and weight monitoring. Endpoint criteria included 20% body mass loss or a score of 2 in specific criteria. Dosing and behavioral procedures began at 4 weeks of age. The elevated plus maze (EPM) was used to assess anxiety-like behavior, recording arm entries and time spent in compartments. The spatial novelty Y-maze was used to assess spatial novelty seeking behavior, recording arm entries and time spent during habituation and test phases. Mouse tissues were processed for histology and immunostaining. Brains were fixed, cryoprotected, embedded, sectioned, and stained.  Gastrointestinal tract and lung tissues were processed, sectioned, and stained. Multiplex chemokine assay was performed on mouse plasma to measure chemokine levels. Microscopy and image processing were performed on stained sections and whole mounts. Cilia morphology and function were analyzed.  Sholl analysis was performed on microglia images. Statistical analysis was performed using t-tests and ANOVA.
chunks.chunk_summary: Mouse studies used MeCP2-null mice and wild-type littermates, with behavioral tests (EPM, Y-maze), histological analysis, immunostaining, and chemokine assays to assess drug efficacy and underlying mechanisms.
chunks.authors: ["2 computational network analysis", "CRISPR-enabled in vivo disease modeling", "9 2 Laboratory of Mucosal Barrier Pathobiology", "Department of Pathology", "Brigham and Women’s", "17 * Contributed equally to this manuscript", "21 CLSB5", "3 Blackfan Circle"]

chunks.text: CRISPR was used to generate a mosaic MeCP2 knockdown in Xenopus laevis tadpoles to model the heterogeneity of Rett syndrome. Injection of Cas9 with sgRNAs targeting MeCP2 resulted in varying degrees of knockdown, mimicking the mosaicism in human patients. Rett tadpoles exhibited abnormal swimming behaviors, including darting and circling, resembling repetitive motions in human patients, and also displayed seizure-like behavior. MeCP2 RNA and protein levels were reduced heterogeneously across tissues. Transcriptomic analysis revealed subtle gene expression changes, with a small number of genes significantly altered, primarily involved in metabolic, developmental, and signal transduction pathways. Gene co-expression network analysis showed reorganization following MeCP2 knockdown, with BDNF emerging as a stronger network hub. Comparison with published datasets from other Rett models and human patients revealed species-specific clustering but a common gene signature with subtle expression changes. Cross-species network analysis identified conserved sub-networks and key regulators like WNT8B, NR4A3, and SOD2, involved in oxidative metabolism.
chunks.chunk_summary: The CRISPR-generated Xenopus tadpole model of Rett syndrome recapitulates key features of the human disease, including phenotypic heterogeneity, behavioral abnormalities, and subtle but widespread transcriptomic changes, with conserved gene networks across species.
chunks.authors: ["2 computational network analysis", "CRISPR-enabled in vivo disease modeling", "9 2 Laboratory of Mucosal Barrier Pathobiology", "Department of Pathology", "Brigham and Women’s", "17 * Contributed equally to this manuscript", "21 CLSB5", "3 Blackfan Circle"]

chunks.text: The nemoCAD computational framework was developed to predict drugs reversing the Rett transcriptome signature. Unlike existing signature-based tools, nemoCAD uses a Bayesian network approach incorporating gene-gene and drug-gene interactions, reducing the impact of tissue- or species-specific biases. Probabilistic network maps were generated for each drug in the LINCS database, using data from single gene knockouts/knockdowns and drug perturbations. By comparing transcriptomic data from MeCP2 knockdown tadpoles and controls, differentially expressed genes were identified. Drugs were ranked based on their predicted ability to reverse transcriptomic changes, considering both single gene and network-level effects.  Selected drugs were screened in Rett tadpoles, assessing seizure-like events. Vorinostat and ivermectin showed time-dependent reductions in seizure score, with vorinostat prioritized for further studies due to its higher predicted score, pharmacokinetics, and blood-brain barrier penetration. Both vorinostat and trofinetide (positive control) reduced seizure-like phenotypes and increased viability in tadpoles.
chunks.topic: Computational Drug Prediction and Tadpole Screening
chunks.chunk_summary: nemoCAD, a novel computational tool using a Bayesian network approach, predicted vorinostat and ivermectin as potential Rett treatments, which was validated in Xenopus tadpole screening, with vorinostat showing promising efficacy.
chunks.authors: ["2 computational network analysis", "CRISPR-enabled in vivo disease modeling", "9 2 Laboratory of Mucosal Barrier Pathobiology", "Department of Pathology", "Brigham and Women’s", "17 * Contributed equally to this manuscript", "21 CLSB5", "3 Blackfan Circle"]

chunks.text: Thermal proteome profiling revealed that vorinostat and ivermectin bind to proteins involved in acetylation metabolism, suggesting a mechanism involving restoration of acetyl-CoA metabolism and post-translational acetylation. Analysis of tadpole tissues showed bidirectional shifts in α-tubulin acetylation depending on tissue type. α-tubulin was hypoacetylated in brain regions and hyperacetylated in the GI tract and olfactory multiciliated cells of Rett tadpoles. Vorinostat restored cilia length and orientation in multiciliated cells and rescued ciliary function, as measured by microbead clearance.  Increased isolectin B4-positive (ib4+) cells in the GI tract of Rett tadpoles, indicative of inflammation, was also reversed by vorinostat.
chunks.topic: Drug Mechanisms and Effects in Tadpoles
chunks.chunk_summary: Vorinostat's mechanism of action in tadpoles appears to involve modulation of acetylation metabolism and restoration of α-tubulin acetylation patterns, leading to improved ciliary function and reduced GI inflammation.
chunks.authors: ["2 computational network analysis", "CRISPR-enabled in vivo disease modeling", "9 2 Laboratory of Mucosal Barrier Pathobiology", "Department of Pathology", "Brigham and Women’s", "17 * Contributed equally to this manuscript", "21 CLSB5", "3 Blackfan Circle"]

chunks.text: Vorinostat's efficacy was evaluated in a MeCP2-/Y mouse model.  Both vorinostat and trofinetide improved disease-related parameters, including diarrhea and motor function, when administered intraperitoneally starting at p31. Vorinostat showed better neurological function improvement in the elevated plus maze. Both drugs enhanced spatial novelty Y-maze performance and improved diarrhea scores.  Microglia in MeCP2-/Y mice exhibited stunted morphology, indicative of inflammation, which was restored by vorinostat.  Serum inflammatory markers were also reduced by vorinostat. Oral vorinostat administered after symptom onset prevented worsening of symptoms, improved weight gain, and enhanced cognitive performance in EPM and Y mazes, while trofinetide was ineffective.  Vorinostat also improved mobility, gait, hindlimb clasping, diarrhea, and breathing.  Hyperacetylation of α-tubulin in lung bronchioles and disrupted α-tubulin acetylation in femoral muscle were rescued by vorinostat.  In the colon, vorinostat reversed vacuolization and neutrophil infiltrate and normalized α-tubulin acetylation, while trofinetide had mixed effects.
chunks.chunk_summary: Vorinostat demonstrated broad efficacy in a mouse Rett model, improving neurological function, reducing inflammation, restoring α-tubulin acetylation, and improving various disease-related parameters, even when administered orally after symptom onset.
chunks.authors: ["2 computational network analysis", "CRISPR-enabled in vivo disease modeling", "9 2 Laboratory of Mucosal Barrier Pathobiology", "Department of Pathology", "Brigham and Women’s", "17 * Contributed equally to this manuscript", "21 CLSB5", "3 Blackfan Circle"]

chunks.text: This study demonstrates the value of combining computational network analysis with CRISPR-generated in vivo disease models for drug discovery. The Xenopus tadpole model effectively captured Rett syndrome heterogeneity and provided results that translated well to a mouse model. The target-agnostic computational approach, nemoCAD, enabled the discovery of novel mechanisms and drugs with broad efficacy across multiple organs. Vorinostat's ability to normalize both hypo- and hyperacetylated tubulin suggests a complex mechanism beyond HDAC inhibition.  Importantly, vorinostat showed efficacy in the mouse model even after symptom onset, offering a more clinically relevant pre-clinical benchmark. This platform offers the potential for developing single small molecule therapeutics addressing multiple disease pathways and enables the discovery of hidden therapeutic mechanisms for new drug development.
chunks.chunk_summary: The combined computational and in vivo approach presented here offers a powerful platform for drug discovery in complex diseases like Rett syndrome, enabling the identification of novel mechanisms and drugs with broad efficacy, even after symptom onset.
chunks.authors: ["2 computational network analysis", "CRISPR-enabled in vivo disease modeling", "9 2 Laboratory of Mucosal Barrier Pathobiology", "Department of Pathology", "Brigham and Women’s", "17 * Contributed equally to this manuscript", "21 CLSB5", "3 Blackfan Circle"]

chunks.text: Novak, Lin, Sperry, Vigneault, Gardner, and Ingber conceived and directed the study. Various authors conducted animal studies, in vitro analyses, CRISPR model generation, bioinformatic analysis, and computational drug prediction. Loomba and Novak designed and developed the nemoCAD software. Turner guided tissue staining studies. Novak and Ingber wrote the manuscript, with all authors reviewing and contributing.
chunks.chunk_summary: The authors detail their individual contributions to the study, including conception, experimentation, analysis, software development, and manuscript preparation.
